cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Egyptian Gazette THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTABLISHED 1830. Editor und Kanagar . • R. SNELLING Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFB. - SATURDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1906 THE METRIC SYSTEM According to Reuter's telegram of Thursday, the adoption of the metric Nystem by the firm of Messrs. Kynoch Limited, of whose board Mr. Arthur Chamberlain is chairman, has fallen as a bomb upon the commercial world of Great Britain. Mr. Chamberlain expresses the opinion that the firm is only anticipating general reformation which must soon come in England, and mys that they are thereby reducing the cost of their calculations and in creasing their export trade. The telegram, however, does not make clear to what ettent the metric system (in the literal and original meaning of the word "metric") has been adopted. A few years ago "metric" system was suggested with an inch unit as basis, and we remain in ignorance as to whether the firm has adopted the inch or the metre unit. No worse method for weighing and measuring than the one which has held sway in England for centuries could be conceived, and scientists were long since compelled to discard it and base all their calculations upon the infinitely more rational metric system. That system has stood the test of use satisfactorily, whereas ours has proved most clumsy and detrimental to our trade with foreign countries. The general adoption of the metric system into our country could be effected with very little cost and labour were the inch to be taken as the unit of length, but the entire changing of the inch unit would be very costly and a great obstrue. tion to the introduction of the more scientific system. Assuming, therefore, that we are about to adopt the metric system, which we should have done very many years ago.--the question still remains, what shall we take as our unit ! A uniformity of systems and units would greatly simplity interchange of trade between us and other countries, but can it be obtained? There are indeed two methods by which such a consommation could be reached. The first, and the one to which we incline the more readily, is that the inch unit should be adopted in the metric system, and that the some 550,000,000 people who use it should force the 150,000,000 people who use the metre unit to adopt the former. The second method is the adoption of the metre as a length unit by Greater Britain, which would be a terrific sacrifice. It is not the adoption of the metrie system which would prove a diffi culty, but the adoption of the metre length unit. The clumsinesss and impractibility of our systems of calculations are universally recognised, and reform is, therefore, greatly to be desired, but we would hardly counsel the adoption of the metre unit. A nation who divides a square pole into thirty and a quarter square yards, who follows such a system of recording temperatures, the bare mention of which makes a scientist shud. nder, indeed whose every mathematical calcula. tion is ridiculously laborious, must be content to run an uneven race. It behoves us, there. fore, to adopt the general decimal system used by other countries. Up to 1897 the irregular and arbitrary nature of the British standards was enforced by law, but in August of that year Parlia ment sanctioned the use of the metric system, which up to the present no British firm has been sufficiently courageous to adopt. In the metrie system there are five principal units, those of length, ares, volume, capacity, and weight. The unit of length is the metre; the unit of area is the square metre; the unit of volume is the cubic metre; the unit of capacity is the litre, which is one-tenth of a metre ; and the unit of weight is a gram, i.e. the weight of water contained in one-thousandth of litre. Such is the system which we ought to adopt, with the exception that the inch should take the place of the metre. The whole system is based upon a single measurement of length and from it we can find out by simple calculation the weight of known volumes of different substances. But the English system has the dis advantage of being variable as well as arbitrary, as is instanced by the existence of two hundred different weights for weighing corn, as an example of which we might note that 46 Sutherland pounds of an equal 240 Cornish pounds. Lord Kelvin denounced the English system as time wasting and brain-destroying in its confusions, and we heartily agree with him. These are not the only disadvantages, Many firms have to spend hundreds of pounds year in the necessary transcription of English weights and measures to the metrical system mnd vice versá, and, moreover, England is continually losing orders owing to her bad system, In many,and probably in the majority of cases, the prices of competing firms differ very little, and the question of convenience invulved in che use or non-use of the metric system may easily decide who gets the order. BRITISH POSTAL ORDERS. TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, - With reference to the paragrapb "Britisb Postal Orders" published in your com bar of the 18th inst, allow me to call be attention of those of your readers, who may possibly employ postal o.ders us remittances, to the fast that, if they want to avoid trouble. they should not fail to register the letter in which the orders are encored. My reason for saying this is that a few weeks ago I wrote to the postmaster in Cairo, reporting that a postal order I had sent to a firm in Malta was never reoaived by them. I therefore requested that payment sbould be stopped, but, in spite of my mentioning the bomber of the counterfoil, which is still in my possession, the reply from tbe Postal Alministration was to the effect that "The Post Office is not responsible for the loss of the order in question as it was sent by ordinary post instead of registered." Uo. Hortonately the amount was only for a few shillings, otherwise, I would have adopted other wensures towards the Postal Adminis tratioo, who is reaping the benefit of an amount wbioh bas not been paid to tbeir debit.-Yours truly, I. JOINTS SHAPBLESS WITH RHEUMATISM The Patient, a Man of 75, also Suf. fered from Lumbago, Sciatica, Dizziness and Pains in the Head, Urinary Disorders, and Gravel. Mr. William Davis, 96, Brereton Road, Rugeley, England, says : -“I am 75 years old, but I am not too old to have found out how good Doan's Backache Kidney Pills are. They have brought me great comfort, and I can highly recommend them. "My work has always exposed me to the weather, and many a time I have got wet through to the skin. In my own mind I have no doubt that this is what brought on the sciatica and lumbago from which I first suffered 12 years ago. I was confined to my bed for a long time, and the agony I underwent was terrible. I also had rheumatism, and my joints were shapeless with it. . "Occasionally my head was so bad that I was light headed; many a time I have come over so dizzy that, but for some handy support, I should have fallen. The kidney secretions were scalding in passing, and full of gravel. "After trying all manner of cures,' and spending pounds on doctors' medicine, without getting any relief, I went under hospital treatment, yet I could no get well. "I had read a good deal about Doan's Back ache Kidney Pills, and my friends had urged me to try them, so at last I got some, and by the time the first box was finished I was certainly better. Encouraged, I went on with the medicine, and now I can truthfully say! that it is many a long year since I felt so well as I do to day. I can take quite a long walk without exhaustion -a thing I had not been able to do for years before I began with Doan's Backache Kidney Pills." Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box. Societe Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d'Egypte. JOINT SYSTÈME BUHNE pour manchons de tuyaux d'eau et de gaz. . Manchon d'un tuyau de 3 mm de diamètre rende Hanche par la laine de plomb Buhne et sur la une profonde 30 Atinospheres JUAGU'présent on assemblait les manchons de tuyaux en introduisant tout d'abord une tres de chanvre et en coulant du plomb dans la partie restée vie, puis on mata le plomb coulé. Notre nouveau système de raccord étanche se comporte wut autrement. Nous employons au lieu de plomb fondu la laine du plomb brevetée en tres es de 1 m de longueur et pesant t oul kilog. suivant les manchons, et procédons summe suit : Après avoir tout d'abord introduit et comprimé la treenederhanvre, on prend une tresse de laine de plomb ou une partie seulement de la trese, selon la force du joint, on learvule autour du tuyau et on la mate fortement dans le manchon ; on répete l'opération jusqu'à ce que le manchon soit complètement plein et bien maté. Par le fait que le matage commence déjà au fond du manchon . . directement sur la troos do chanvre. la laine de plomb we transforme en une FRAASE homogene, su moyen de laquelle on realise non seulement une étanchéité parfaite, mais encore résistance bwaunup plus considerable qu'auparavant. Des essais de notre nouveau systeme de raccordement étanche ont ét faits nun wulement dans no urines, mais ausRien beaucoup de villes qui en font l'étude a différents points de vue. Ainsi nous avons réalisé des joints de tuyaux de 300 et 450 m de diamètre d'apre notre procédé et wiumis ces joints pendant des semaines à une pression constante de 20 atmospheres que le raccord cedat. On réunit galernt i bouti bout 4 tuyaux de 100 mm de diametre d'après notre procédé : on plaça les doux extrémités sur deur supports de telle sorte que la partie intermédiaire ne fût pas soutenue. On ne constata ainsi aucune flexion. Par contre un owai analogue avec des joints en plomb fondu acum une flexion considérable. next ainsi démontre qu'anec notre procede on obtient un joint bien étanche et une résistance mécanique bien plus grande qu'autrefois. Notre nouveau procédé de raccordement étanche offre en outre l'immense avantage de permettre de travailler par tous les temps et sans nécessiter la mise a se des manchons. Outre ces énormes avantages techniques, notre procédé présente vis-à-vis des anciens prookle encore d'autres L'appareil encombrant pour le coulage plomb el mupprimé, et avec le tout le combustible tel que bois coke ; la perte de plomb à la coulée est toutee, UN pprune de même le suhde, la main dawere de moulage des této de manchons et la main d'entre de coulage. Dans notre procédé il ne faut plus que des mateurs, Il s'ensuit que notte méthode rend le travail plus économique que l'ancien prooide, sans parler den avantages concernant l'hygiene. AUG. div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.
